pageContext.claim: “We cannot get our product in [to the European Union]. It's very very tough. And yet they send their product to us -- no taxes, very little taxes, it's very unfair. I've had a lot of problems with the European Union.”
pageContext.analysis: Trump is wrong here. As a World Trade Organization member, countries in the European Union face the “Most Favored Nation tariff” when they export a product to the United States. There is a potentially different tariff for every product exported to the United States, countries have negotiated various reductions (product-by-product) with US negotiators since 1947. On average, across all products, the US MFN tariff is 3.5 percent – so on average that is what a company from the EU would pay.
